item.title: By: Jerry Shelley
item.dc:creator: Jerry Shelley
item.description: <p>Oooops - yes dojo tooltips do indeed work only if their divs are stored inside the panel or whatever is the source of the partial refresh that contains the controls to be tool-tipped.</p>
item.content:encoded: Oooops – yes dojo tooltips do indeed work only if their divs are stored inside the panel or whatever is the source of the partial refresh that contains the controls to be tool-tipped.

item.title: By: Jerry Shelley
item.dc:creator: Jerry Shelley
item.description: <p>Just discovered that dojo Tooltips don't work for controls that have been hidden and revealed by a partial refresh, eg after a radio button option has been chosen. :-(</p>
item.content:encoded: Just discovered that dojo Tooltips don't work for controls that have been hidden and revealed by a partial refresh, eg after a radio button option has been chosen. üôÅ

item.title: By: Keith Strickland
item.dc:creator: Keith Strickland
item.description: <p>OK, I found it. Seems Lotus Domino 8.5.0 does not fully support IE 8. I found this entry over on the XPages Wiki http://www.youatnotes.de/web/youatnotes/wiki-xpages.nsf/dx/Browser_compatibility</p><p>The code listed there solved my issue, thanks for the speedy response :)</p><p>Keith</p>
item.content:encoded:
OK, I found it. Seems Lotus Domino 8.5.0 does not fully support IE 8. I found this entry over on the XPages Wiki http://www.youatnotes.de/web/youatnotes/wiki-xpages.nsf/dx/Browser_compatibility

The code listed there solved my issue, thanks for the speedy response üôÇ

Keith

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>@Keith - I can't think of any reason why it wouldn't work with IE (apart from it being a POC). It is a technique I have used several times now and it has worked in IE6 / 7 / 8 during testing so not sure what the problem is there.</p>
item.content:encoded: @Keith – I can’t think of any reason why it wouldn’t work with IE (apart from it being a POC). It is a technique I have used several times now and it has worked in IE6 / 7 / 8 during testing so not sure what the problem is there.

item.title: By: Keith Strickland
item.dc:creator: Keith Strickland
item.description: <p>Great tip Matt, Thanks! Does this work for you in Internet Explorer? It works great in firefox however I get an error in IE (Line: 20 Error: Member not found) when adding the dijit.Tooltip resource. I've tried dijit.Tooltip.js also to no avail.</p>
item.content:encoded: Great tip Matt, Thanks! Does this work for you in Internet Explorer? It works great in firefox however I get an error in IE (Line: 20 Error: Member not found) when adding the dijit.Tooltip resource. I’ve tried dijit.Tooltip.js also to no avail.

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>OK I corrected the code so it is unstruckout (?!?) now :-)</p>
item.content:encoded: OK I corrected the code so it is unstruckout (?!?) now üôÇ

item.title: By: John "HeyHeyJP" Palmer
item.dc:creator: John "HeyHeyJP" Palmer
item.description: <p>@Tim / @Matt</p><p>Thanks. Found the error (capital T) in one place and fixed that before testing page, but didn't get all them, so didn't know that's what was causing the problem. Working now without error, even keeping in your struckout lines (strikedout?).</p>
item.content:encoded:
@Tim / @Matt

Thanks. Found the error (capital T) in one place and fixed that before testing page, but didn’t get all them, so didn’t know that’s what was causing the problem. Working now without error, even keeping in your struckout lines (strikedout?).

item.title: By: Declan Lynch
item.dc:creator: Declan Lynch
item.description: <p>I find having the tooltip as a custom control works great for me as a write once use many control. I was interested by Tim's comment above about putting richer content into the tooltip so I tried an experiement of using an Editable Area in the tooltip custom control and it seems to work fairly well.</p><p>I will write up an example and post it soon.</p>
item.content:encoded:
I find having the tooltip as a custom control works great for me as a write once use many control. I was interested by Tim’s comment above about putting richer content into the tooltip so I tried an experiement of using an Editable Area in the tooltip custom control and it seems to work fairly well.

I will write up an example and post it soon.

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>@Tim - Aha good spot, I really shouldn't blog while trying to do three other things at once is the lesson from this :-)</p>
item.content:encoded: @Tim – Aha good spot, I really shouldn’t blog while trying to do three other things at once is the lesson from this üôÇ

item.title: By: Tim Tripcony
item.dc:creator: Tim Tripcony
item.description: <p>@Matt / @John, that's because the second T should be lowercase:</p><p>xp:dojoModule name="dijit.Tooltip"</p><p>When you include a dojo module - whether through a dojoModule resource or a dojo.require() statement in client-side JS - it's not just trying to load the extra script tag, it also verifies the object that tag creates, and since JS is case-sensitive, the object verification will fail if the case doesn't match.</p>
item.content:encoded:
@Matt / @John, that’s because the second T should be lowercase:

xp:dojoModule name="dijit.Tooltip"

When you include a dojo module – whether through a dojoModule resource or a dojo.require() statement in client-side JS – it’s not just trying to load the extra script tag, it also verifies the object that tag creates, and since JS is case-sensitive, the object verification will fail if the case doesn’t match.
